de.esoco.lib.json

Class JsonBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.json.JsonBuilder

  • public class JsonBuilder
extends java.lang.Object
    A builder for JSON strings that can append arbitrary data objects to a JSON string. This includes support for Relatable and Relation objects. If such an object is appended either all or the given relations of that object will be appended to the JSON string. This includes the recursive evaluation for other relatable objects that are referenced from relations.
    See Also:
    JsonParser, Json

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description

      • appendRelatable

        public JsonBuilder appendRelatable(Relatable rObject,
                                   java.util.Collection<RelationType<?>> rRelationTypes,
                                   boolean bRecursive)
        Appends the relations of a Relatable object to this JSON string as a JSON object structure. See appendRelations(Relatable, Collection) for details about how the relations are appended.

        The boolean parameter defines whether this method will be applied recursively to relatable objects in relation or if only their string representation will be appended. Using recursion should be used with caution as circular references can cause stack overflows.

        Parameters:
        rObject - The object to append the relations of
        rRelationTypes - The types of the relation to be converted to JSON (NULL for all)
        bRecursive - TRUE to recursively append all relatables stored in the relations of the object
        Returns:
        This instance for concatenation
        See Also:
        appendRelations(Relatable, Collection)

      • appendRelations

        public JsonBuilder appendRelations(Relatable rObject,
                                   java.util.Collection<RelationType<?>> rRelationTypes)
        Appends the relations of a Relatable object to this JSON string. If enabled references to other related objects are converted recursively. If no explicit relation types are provided all relations of the object will be converted to JSON. In that case it is necessary that there are no cycles in the relations, i.e. objects referring each other either directly (like in parent-child relationships) or indirectly. It is possible to exclude certain relation types from the processing by indicating them through exclude(RelationType).

        Alternatively the object can specify the relation types to serialize with the annotation Json.JSON_SERIALIZED_TYPES. If that is present only the relation types stored therein will be serialized.

        Furthermore all relation values in the source object must be compatible with JSON. That means they must either have a datatype that can be converted directly or valid a string representation. The latter can be achieved by registering a global string conversion through Conversions.registerStringConversion(Class,InvertibleFunction). If these requirements are not met the resulting JSON string will probably not be parseable by the class JsonParser.

        Parameters:
        rObject - The object to append the relations of
        rRelationTypes - The types of the relation to be converted to JSON (NULL for all)
        Returns:
        This instance for concatenation

      • appendString

        public JsonBuilder appendString(java.lang.String sStringValue)
        Appends a string value by wrapping it in the JSON string delimiters. The string will not be escaped. That need to be done separately by invoking Json.escape(String) if necessary.
        Parameters:
        sStringValue - sText The text string to append
        Returns:
        This instance for concatenation

      • exclude

        public JsonBuilder exclude(RelationType<?> rExcludedType)
        Excludes a certain relation type from the relation-based conversions in this class. A relation type added through this method will be ignored by appendRelations(Relatable, Collection) if this method is invoked without an explicit list of relation types. This class already contains a default list of relation types that either have no meaningful JSON representation or would prevent the JSON generation. Appending a single single relation explicitly is not affected by this setting.
        Parameters:
        rExcludedType - The relation type to be excluded from the JSON generation
        Returns:
        This instance for concatenation

      • withNamespaces

        public JsonBuilder withNamespaces()
        Enables the addition of namespaces to the names of properties created from relation types. The namespace will always be lower case names separated by dots, independent of the TextConvert.IdentifierStyle used for the actual property name.

        By default this option is disabled.

        Returns:
        This instance for fluent invocation
